questions.text: Subperiosteal erosion is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hyperparathyroidism Subperiosteal erosion is a characteristic radiological finding in hyperparathyroidism, particularly in the primary form due to excess secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH increases bone resorption by stimulating osteoclast activity, leading to cortical bone thinning and subperiosteal bone resorption, especially at the radial aspect of the middle phalanges of the hand (a hallmark feature). Other skeletal manifestations include salt-and-pepper skull appearance, brown tumors (osteitis fibrosa cystica), and generalized osteopenia. Incorrect Options: A. Scurvy – Incorrect because scurvy (vitamin C deficiency) primarily affects bone through defective collagen synthesis, leading to periosteal hemorrhages, fragile bones, and scorbutic rosary in ribs. However, it does not cause subperiosteal erosion. C. Hypoparathyroidism – Incorrect because it is associated with low PTH levels, which result in decreased bone resorption, leading to increased bone density rather than subperiosteal erosion. Radiologically, it may present with basal ganglia calcifications and dense bones (osteosclerosis) rather than bone resorption. D. Rickets – Incorrect because rickets (vitamin D deficiency) leads to defective mineralization of osteoid, causing bone softening and deformities like bowing of legs. It primarily affects growth plates (rachitic rosary, widened metaphyses) rather than subperiosteal erosion.

questions.text: 'Onion peel' appearance on radiograph is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ewing’s sarcoma. The "onion peel" appearance on radiographs is a characteristic feature of Ewing’s sarcoma, a highly malignant small round cell tumor of bone. This appearance results from layers of periosteal new bone formation due to repeated episodes of bone destruction and repair. Ewing’s sarcoma typically affects children and adolescents, with a predilection for the diaphysis of long bones such as the femur, tibia, and pelvis. The tumor's aggressive nature leads to rapid periosteal reactions, forming multiple concentric layers of bone deposition, resembling the layers of an onion on X-ray. Additional radiographic features may include moth-eaten bone destruction, cortical disruption, and soft tissue extension. Incorrect Options: A. Giant Cell Tumor (GCT): Incorrect. GCT usually occurs in the epiphysis of long bones and presents as a lytic, expansile lesion with a “soap bubble” appearance on radiographs. Unlike Ewing’s sarcoma, it lacks periosteal reactions and does not exhibit the "onion peel" pattern. C. Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma): Incorrect. Osteosarcoma typically shows a “sunburst” pattern due to aggressive bone formation and a Codman’s triangle, which results from periosteal lifting. This is different from the layered periosteal reaction seen in Ewing’s sarcoma. D. Multiple Myeloma: Incorrect. Multiple myeloma is a hematologic malignancy that causes “punched-out lytic lesions” or “raindrop skull” appearance rather than a periosteal reaction. It primarily affects the bone marrow and does not produce an onion-skin appearance on radiographs.

questions.text: Fraying at the ends of long bones is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rickets. Fraying at the ends of long bones is a characteristic radiographic feature of rickets, a disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency, calcium deficiency, or phosphate metabolism abnormalities. The deficient mineralization of the growth plate results in fraying, cupping, splaying, and widening of the metaphysis, particularly at sites of rapid growth such as the distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius. The earliest radiographic sign of rickets is the loss of the provisional zone of calcification, seen at the metaphysis. In healing rickets, a white line of healing appears as mineralization improves. Incorrect Options: B. Scurvy: Incorrect. Scurvy (vitamin C deficiency) primarily affects collagen synthesis, leading to fragile bones and bleeding tendencies. Radiographic findings include Frankel’s line (dense zone of provisional calcification), Wimberger’s ring sign (scurvy scorbutic rosary), and Pelkan spurs (bony projections at metaphysis), but fraying is not a feature. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta: Incorrect. This is a genetic disorder of collagen synthesis, leading to brittle bones and multiple fractures. X-rays typically show osteopenia, bowing of long bones, and multiple fractures, but fraying is not a characteristic feature. D. Congenital Syphilis: Incorrect. In congenital syphilis, characteristic radiographic findings include Wimberger’s sign (destruction of the medial part of the proximal tibia), periosteal reaction, and metaphyseal lucencies (saber shin deformity). It does not show fraying of the metaphysis like rickets.

questions.text: Osseous metastasis is most common if tumor is in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bronchus (Lung Cancer). Osseous (bone) metastasis is most commonly seen in malignancies that have a high propensity for hematogenous spread. Lung cancer, especially bronchogenic carcinoma, is one of the most common primary tumors to metastasize to bones due to its rich vascular supply and aggressive nature. Bone metastases from lung cancer are often osteolytic, leading to pathological fractures, bone pain, and hypercalcemia. The common sites of bone metastasis include the vertebrae, pelvis, ribs, and proximal long bones. Other tumors frequently causing bone metastases include breast, prostate, kidney, and thyroid cancers. Incorrect Options: B. Colon Cancer: Incorrect. Colorectal cancer typically spreads to the liver (via the portal venous system) and lungs, rather than bones. Bone metastases from colorectal cancer are rare. C. Pancreatic Cancer: Incorrect. Pancreatic cancer primarily metastasizes to the liver, peritoneum, and lungs. Bone metastases are uncommon in pancreatic malignancies. D. Adrenal Cancer: Incorrect. Adrenal tumors, such as adrenocortical carcinoma, primarily spread to the lungs, liver, and peritoneum. Bone metastases are rare in adrenal cancers.

questions.text: In Scurvy, wimberger sign is best seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lower end of femur. Wimberger’s sign in scurvy refers to a bilateral, symmetric, well-defined ring of increased density surrounding the epiphyseal center due to subperiosteal hemorrhage and defective collagen synthesis. This sign is best seen in the lower end of the femur, which is a common site for scurvy-related changes in growing children. It indicates periosteal elevation and cortical thinning, commonly found in vitamin C deficiency. Incorrect Options: B. Lower end of radius: Incorrect. Though scurvy affects multiple long bones, Wimberger’s sign is most prominent in the femur, not the radius. The lower end of the radius may show metaphyseal irregularities, but it is not the primary site for this sign. C. Patella: Incorrect. The patella is less commonly affected in scurvy, and Wimberger’s sign is not observed here. D. Upper end of radius: Incorrect. Similar to the lower end, the upper end of the radius is not the most common site for Wimberger’s sign.

questions.text: Soap bubble appearance is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumor, GCT). The "soap bubble appearance" on radiographs is characteristic of osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumor, GCT). This appearance results from eccentric, expansile, and lytic lesions with multiple septations seen in the epiphyseal region of long bones, commonly the distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius. GCT is a locally aggressive tumor with well-defined but non-sclerotic margins, and it often extends into the subarticular bone. The soap bubble pattern arises due to a trabeculated, multiloculated bone destruction process. Incorrect Options: A. Osteoid Osteoma: Incorrect. Osteoid osteoma is a small, well-defined radiolucent lesion (nidus) surrounded by reactive sclerosis. It is usually seen in the cortex of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia), but it does not show a soap bubble appearance. B. Osteochondroma: Incorrect. Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that appears as a bony outgrowth (exostosis) with a cartilage cap. It does not present with a soap bubble pattern. D. Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma): Incorrect. Osteosarcoma typically presents with a sunburst pattern due to aggressive periosteal bone formation and may also show Codman’s triangle (periosteal lifting), but it does not have a soap bubble appearance.

questions.text: All of the following are radiological features of tuberculosis of spine except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Marked osteoblastic response. Spinal tuberculosis (Pott’s disease) is a chronic granulomatous infection that primarily affects the anterior part of the vertebral body, leading to progressive destruction and deformity. The hallmark radiological features include vertebral body destruction, intervertebral disc space narrowing, kyphotic deformity, and paravertebral abscess formation. Correct Radiological Features: A. Large paravertebral abscess → Correct Tuberculous infection often causes cold abscess formation in the paravertebral region, which may be large due to minimal inflammatory response. A classic finding is the “fusiform or balloon-shaped” abscess along the vertebral column. C. Marked collapse of vertebra → Correct Tuberculosis leads to progressive destruction of the vertebral bodies, often resulting in severe collapse (vertebral plana) and kyphotic deformity (gibbus formation). D. Decreased joint space → Correct Unlike pyogenic infections, tuberculosis causes gradual disc space narrowing due to slow destruction of the intervertebral disc and adjacent endplates. This is a distinguishing feature of tuberculous spondylitis.

questions.text: Multiple 'punched out holes' in skull are seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Multiple myeloma. Multiple "punched-out" holes in the skull are a characteristic radiological finding in multiple myeloma, a malignant plasma cell disorder. These well-defined, round, lytic lesions occur due to bone resorption without reactive new bone formation. The lesions result from increased osteoclastic activity driven by myeloma cells, leading to bone pain, fractures, and hypercalcemia. This appearance is best seen on a skull X-ray and is sometimes referred to as a "raindrop skull" due to the scattered lytic defects. Incorrect Options: A. Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism causes subperiosteal bone resorption, commonly affecting the radial aspect of the phalanges. Skull X-rays may show a "salt and pepper" appearance rather than discrete punched-out lesions. C. Thalassemia Major: Thalassemia major leads to extramedullary hematopoiesis, causing bone marrow expansion and cortical thinning. The skull X-ray shows a "hair-on-end" or "crew-cut" appearance due to prominent vertical striations, not punched-out lesions. D. Acromegaly: Acromegaly leads to thickening of the skull and enlarged sella turcica, but it does not produce punched-out lesions.

questions.text: Best radiological view for diagnosis of fracture scaphoid is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Oblique. The best radiological view for diagnosing a scaphoid fracture is the oblique view, specifically the posteroanterior (PA) view with ulnar deviation. This position helps in elongating the scaphoid and reducing overlap with surrounding bones, improving fracture visibility. A true scaphoid view (PA wrist with ulnar deviation and sometimes an additional 30° cephalic tilt) is most sensitive for detecting subtle fractures. Incorrect Options: A. Anteroposterior (AP) View The AP view does not provide an optimal angle to visualize the scaphoid, as it often overlaps with other carpal bones, making fractures difficult to detect. B. Lateral View The lateral view is not ideal for detecting scaphoid fractures but is useful for assessing carpal alignment and dislocation. D. Any of the above Not all views are equally effective in diagnosing a scaphoid fracture. The oblique (scaphoid view) is the most reliable for detecting fractures.

questions.text: Osteosarcoma is differentiated from myositis ossificans by radiology by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Peripheral field of differentiation. Osteosarcoma and myositis ossificans both present with ossification, but they can be differentiated radiologically based on the pattern of bone formation. Osteosarcoma: Shows central (medullary) ossification, meaning the tumor forms bone in the center and grows outward. It often appears as an aggressive lesion with a sunburst pattern, Codman’s triangle, and periosteal reaction. Myositis ossificans: Shows peripheral ossification, meaning bone formation occurs at the periphery while the center remains radiolucent (cartilaginous or fibrous). This helps distinguish it from osteosarcoma, which shows chaotic bone formation throughout. Incorrect Options: A. Location: Both conditions can occur in similar locations, such as the long bones, especially around the femur. However, osteosarcoma originates in bone, while myositis ossificans occurs in soft tissue. B. Absence of osteomyelitic changes: Neither condition typically shows osteomyelitic changes (e.g., sequestrum or involucrum), so this is not a key distinguishing factor. C. Shape of swelling: While osteosarcoma presents with an irregular, infiltrative swelling, and myositis ossificans appears more well-defined, this is not the primary distinguishing feature.

questions.text: All are radiological features of ricket except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Narrow growth plate In rickets, the growth plate is widened, not narrowed, due to the failure of normal mineralization and endochondral ossification. The widening of the growth plate is a hallmark feature of rickets, especially at sites of rapid growth like the distal femur and proximal tibia Rickets is a disorder of defective mineralization of the growth plate due to vitamin D deficiency, calcium deficiency, or phosphate metabolism defects. It primarily affects growing children and leads to characteristic radiological changes in the long bones. Incorrect Options: A. Ill-defined epiphysis Due to defective calcification, the epiphyseal centers appear poorly mineralized, blurred, and indistinct on X-ray. C. Frayed and widened metaphysis The metaphysis appears widened and irregular, giving a "fraying" appearance due to defective bone formation. D. Metaphyseal cupping The concave deformation of the metaphysis (cupping) is seen due to inadequate mineralization and the softening of the bone.

questions.text: Which of the following primary produces a radiopaque secondary in bone?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prostate. Radiopaque (osteoblastic) bone metastases result from excessive new bone formation, often leading to sclerotic lesions on radiographs. Among primary tumors, prostate cancer is the most common cause of osteoblastic bone metastases, typically affecting the spine, pelvis, and proximal femur. These lesions appear dense (radiopaque) on X-rays due to abnormal bone deposition. Incorrect Options: B. Thyroid Thyroid cancer (especially follicular carcinoma) typically causes osteolytic (radiolucent) bone metastases, leading to bone destruction rather than sclerosis. C. Kidney Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) also causes osteolytic metastases, often presenting with destructive bone lesions and pathological fractures. D. Breast Breast cancer can cause both osteolytic and osteoblastic metastases, but it predominantly presents as osteolytic lesions. Some cases (notably lobular carcinoma) can have mixed or osteoblastic metastases, but it is not the most characteristic feature.

questions.text: Honeycomb appearance on X-ray is seen in all except:
questions.solution: Wegeners granulomatosis radiographically shows variable features. M/c - nodules with/without cavity, reticulonodular interstitial infiltrates, pulmonary haemorrhage, peripheral wedge like consolidation. Honey combing is seen in all other options.

questions.text: Cortical spur is found in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Scurvy. A cortical spur is a radiological feature seen in Scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency). It appears as a bony projection at the metaphysis, known as the "Pelkan spur", resulting from periosteal elevation due to subperiosteal hemorrhage and defective collagen synthesis. Incorrect Options: A. Rickets Rickets primarily causes metaphyseal cupping, fraying, and widening, but not cortical spurs. C. Hypervitaminosis (likely referring to Hypervitaminosis A or D) Hypervitaminosis A causes periosteal reactions and bone resorption, whereas Hypervitaminosis D leads to hypercalcemia and vascular calcification, but neither condition presents with cortical spurs. D. Fluorosis Fluorosis is associated with generalized osteosclerosis, ligamentous calcification, and increased bone density, not cortical spurs.

choices.text: Obtuse angle of mandible and lengthening of mandible

questions.text: X-ray changes in acromegaly are all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lengthened terminal phalanx. Acromegaly does not lengthen the terminal phalanx. Instead, it causes widening and thickening of the phalanges, giving a spade-like appearance to the hands and feet. Acromegaly is caused by excess growth hormone (GH) secretion, usually due to a pituitary adenoma, leading to bony overgrowth and soft tissue enlargement. The characteristic X-ray findings include widened joint spaces, skull and jaw changes, and premature osteoarthritis. Correct X-ray Findings in Acromegaly: B. Widened Joint Spaces Due to cartilage overgrowth, joint spaces initially widen before degenerative arthritis sets in. C. Obtuse Angle of Mandible and Lengthening of Mandible (Prognathism) Acromegaly causes mandibular overgrowth, resulting in a more obtuse gonial angle and prognathism (enlarged jaw). D. Premature Osteoarthritis Despite initial widening of joint spaces, long-term cartilage overgrowth leads to degenerative changes (osteoarthritis), especially in weight-bearing joints.

questions.text: Most common cause of punched out lesions in phalanges is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Enchondroma. Enchondroma is the most common cause of punched-out lesions in the phalanges. It is a benign cartilage tumor that commonly affects the small bones of the hands and feet, leading to well-defined, lytic, "punched-out" lesions with possible endosteal scalloping. It may be asymptomatic or present with pathological fractures. Multiple enchondromas are seen in Ollier’s disease and Maffucci syndrome. Incorrect Options: B. Chondrosarcoma Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage tumor that typically affects long bones (femur, humerus, pelvis) rather than phalanges. It presents with cortical destruction and soft tissue invasion, unlike the well-contained lytic lesions of enchondroma. C. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) ABC is an expansile, osteolytic lesion that appears soap-bubble-like rather than as discrete punched-out lesions. It commonly affects long bones and vertebrae, not phalanges. D. Multiple Myeloma Multiple myeloma is the most common cause of punched-out lesions in the skull and axial skeleton, but it rarely affects the phalanges.

questions.text: 'Telephone Handle' long bones are seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Thanatophoric Dwarfism Thanatophoric dwarfism is a severe, lethal skeletal dysplasia characterized by: "Telephone handle" appearance of long bones – due to metaphyseal flaring and shortened diaphysis. H-shaped vertebrae – seen due to platyspondyly (flattened vertebrae). Cloverleaf skull (Kleeblattschädel deformity) – due to premature cranial suture closure. Severe pulmonary hypoplasia, leading to neonatal respiratory failure (most common cause of death). Incorrect Options: A. Achondroplasia – No "Telephone Handle" Bones Rhizomelic (proximal) limb shortening but without the typical telephone handle appearance. Frontal bossing, depressed nasal bridge, and trident hands are characteristic. C. Mucopolysaccharidosis – Different Skeletal Features Causes dysostosis multiplex with oar-shaped ribs, bullet-shaped phalanges, and J-shaped sella. No telephone handle appearance of long bones. D. Acromegaly – No Shortening of Bones Causes overgrowth of bone and soft tissue, leading to enlarged hands, feet, and facial bones. No telephone handle appearance or dwarfism.

questions.text: Pantomography is done for except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Transverse fracture of Atlas. Pantomography (Panoramic Radiography) is a specialized imaging technique primarily used in dentistry and maxillofacial imaging. It provides a wide, curved, two-dimensional view of the entire dental arch, jaws, and temporomandibular joints (TMJ) in a single image. However, it is not suitable for evaluating cervical spine fractures, such as a transverse fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra). Atlas fractures require more detailed imaging techniques, such as lateral cervical spine X-ray, open-mouth odontoid view, or CT scan, which offer superior bone resolution and visualization of the C1-C2 complex. Since pantomography does not effectively capture the cervical vertebrae, it is not a preferred modality for diagnosing an atlas fracture. Incorrect Options: A. Dental Caries Pantomography is widely used in dental examinations for detecting dental caries (cavities), periodontal disease, and impacted teeth. It helps visualize the entire dental arch and is useful for screening multiple teeth at once. B. Dental Cyst Pantomography is useful for detecting dental cysts and other pathological lesions in the jawbones, as it provides a comprehensive view of the upper and lower jaw structures. C. TM Joint It is also used for evaluating temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders, including joint degeneration, dislocation, and other abnormalities affecting jaw movement.

questions.text: 'H' shaped vertebra is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sickle Cell Anemia. 'H'-shaped vertebrae (also called Lincoln log vertebrae) is a characteristic radiological finding seen in sickle cell anemia. It occurs due to repeated microvascular occlusions and ischemia of the vertebral end plates, leading to central endplate depression. This results in a biconcave appearance of the vertebral bodies resembling the letter "H". This deformity is most commonly seen in the lumbar and thoracic spine and is caused by bone infarctions due to chronic vaso-occlusion in sickle cell disease. Incorrect Options: A. Phenylketonuria Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a metabolic disorder affecting the nervous system rather than the bones. It does not cause H-shaped vertebrae. C. Hemangioma Vertebral hemangiomas cause a "corduroy cloth" appearance on X-ray and "polka-dot" sign on CT scan, not H-shaped vertebrae. D. Osteoporosis Osteoporosis leads to vertebral compression fractures and wedge-shaped vertebrae, often resulting in kyphosis ("dowager’s hump"), but not an H-shaped deformity.

questions.text: Isotope used in bone scans:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Technetium. Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) is the most commonly used isotope in bone scans. It is typically used in the form of Tc-99m methylene diphosphonate (MDP), which binds to hydroxyapatite in bones, particularly in areas with increased osteoblastic activity. Bone scans using Tc-99m MDP are highly sensitive for detecting bone metastases, fractures, infections (osteomyelitis), and other skeletal abnormalities. Incorrect Options: B. Gallium Gallium-67 is used for infection and tumor imaging, especially in detecting osteomyelitis and inflammatory conditions, but it is not primarily used for routine bone scans. C. Selenium Selenium isotopes are not commonly used in bone scans. Selenium-75 is sometimes used in pancreatic and adrenal imaging but has no role in bone imaging. D. Chromium Chromium-51 is used in red blood cell (RBC) survival studies and spleen imaging, not in bone scans.

questions.text: Stryker's view is used in shoulder joint to visualise:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Recurrent Subluxation. Stryker's View (Stryker Notch View) is a specialized radiographic view of the shoulder joint used primarily to assess Hill-Sachs lesions, which are bony defects on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head seen in cases of recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation or subluxation. The patient is positioned supine with the arm flexed at the elbow and the hand placed on the forehead, allowing optimal visualization of the humeral head and any associated bony defects. Incorrect Options: A. Muscle Calcification Muscle calcifications, such as myositis ossificans, are better seen on standard anteroposterior (AP) or lateral views rather than Stryker's view. C. Subacromial Calcification Subacromial calcification, as seen in calcific tendinitis, is better evaluated using a supraspinatus outlet view or AP shoulder X-ray. D. Bicipital Groove The bicipital groove, where the long head of the biceps tendon resides, is best visualized using a modified AP view or axial view, not Stryker’s view.

questions.text: "Marble bone" appearance is charac­teristic of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osteopetrosis. "Marble bone" appearance refers to increased bone density with a uniform, sclerotic appearance, resembling marble or ivory. This is characteristic of Osteopetrosis (Albers-Schönberg disease), a rare genetic disorder caused by defective osteoclast function, leading to impaired bone resorption and excessive bone mineralization. The bones appear dense and sclerotic on X-ray, but they are also brittle, making them prone to fractures. Classic radiological findings include diffuse bone sclerosis, “bone within a bone” appearance, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of long bones. Incorrect Options: B. Osteogenesis Imperfecta Osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease) is a collagen synthesis disorder, leading to osteopenia (reduced bone density), multiple fractures, and bowing of bones, rather than a marble bone appearance. C. Fluorosis Skeletal fluorosis causes diffuse bone sclerosis and hyperostosis, but it does not produce the characteristic "marble bone" appearance seen in osteopetrosis. Instead, it may show ligamentous calcifications and osteophyte formation. D. Achondroplasia Achondroplasia is a disorder of cartilage formation, leading to shortened long bones, bullet-shaped vertebrae, and narrowing of the spinal canal, but it does not cause a marble-like bone density.

choices.text: Narrowing or absence of the normal zone of provisional calcification
Epiphysis smaller than normal and have characteristic thin pencil line cortex

questions.text: The radiological changes in Rickets are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Narrowing or absence of the normal zone of provisional calcification. In Rickets, there is defective mineralization of the growing bone due to vitamin D deficiency, calcium, or phosphate abnormalities. The most characteristic radiological sign of rickets is the loss or narrowing of the zone of provisional calcification at the metaphysis, which appears as a blurred, frayed, or widened metaphysis on X-ray. This occurs due to the failure of cartilage matrix mineralization. Other characteristic findings include metaphyseal cupping, splaying, and fraying. Incorrect Options: B. Fracture of the bone Rickets primarily causes bone softening and deformities (such as bowing of bones) rather than fractures. However, in severe cases, Looser's zones (pseudofractures) may be seen, but complete fractures are not a defining feature. C. Epiphysis smaller than normal and have characteristic thin pencil line cortex This description is more characteristic of Scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency) rather than Rickets. In scurvy, epiphyseal changes such as Wimberger’s sign (ringed epiphysis) are commonly seen. D. Bowing of the bone While bowing of bones (especially in weight-bearing bones like the tibia and femur) is a late feature of Rickets, it is not an initial radiological change. The primary radiological feature remains the loss of the provisional calcification zone.

questions.text: Normal metacarpal index is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 5.4 to 7.9 The metacarpal index (MI) is a radiological measurement used to assess metacarpal elongation, which is often increased in conditions like Marfan’s syndrome and homocystinuria. Normal Metacarpal Index = 5.4 to 7.9 Arachnodactyly (seen in Marfan’s syndrome, homocystinuria, etc.) = 8.4 to 10.4 Incorrect Options: A. Less than 5.4 – Below Normal Range A metacarpal index less than 5.4 is considered below normal and is not diagnostic for any specific condition. C. 8.4 to 10.4 – Indicative of Arachnodactyly This higher range is associated with Marfan syndrome and homocystinuria, where long, slender fingers (arachnodactyly) are a key feature. D. More than 10.4 – Excessively High Extremely rare and usually indicates severe arachnodactyly or other connective tissue disorders

questions.text: "Champagne Glass" pelvis is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Achondroplasia. "Champagne Glass" pelvis is a characteristic radiological finding in Achondroplasia, a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene, leading to impaired endochondral ossification and dwarfism. In pelvic X-rays, the iliac bones appear short and flared, and the interacetabular distance is increased, creating a widened pelvic inlet that resembles the shape of a champagne glass. This feature is an important diagnostic clue in achondroplasia. Incorrect Options: B. Cretinism Cretinism (Congenital Hypothyroidism) affects skeletal development, leading to delayed bone age, widened sutures, and epiphyseal dysgenesis, but it does not produce a "champagne glass" pelvis. C. Down's Syndrome Down syndrome is associated with hypoplastic iliac wings, flared iliac bones, and shallow acetabula, but the pelvis does not take on the "champagne glass" appearance. D. Congenital Dislocation of the Hip (CDH) CDH (Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip) leads to shallow acetabula, superior and lateral displacement of the femoral head, and increased acetabular angle, but not the characteristic "champagne glass" pelvis.

choices.text: Dysbaric osteonecrosis are commonly juxta articular
Are often diaphyseal in sickle cell disease

questions.text: In bone infarcts, all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Occur in thalassemia major (Incorrect statement). Thalassemia major does not cause infarcts but results in bone marrow hyperplasia, cortical thinning, and osteoporosis. Bone infarcts refer to areas of ischemic necrosis within the bone due to compromised blood supply. They are associated with conditions like sickle cell disease, dysbaric osteonecrosis, Gaucher’s disease, and acute pancreatitis. However, thalassemia major does not typically cause bone infarcts; instead, it leads to marrow hyperplasia and expansion, cortical thinning, and pathologic fractures. Incorrect Options: A. Dysbaric osteonecrosis is commonly juxta-articular Dysbaric osteonecrosis (seen in divers and individuals exposed to decompression sickness) affects juxta-articular regions, particularly the femoral and humeral heads. B. Occur in Gaucher's disease Gaucher’s disease leads to bone infarcts due to infiltration of Gaucher cells, causing vascular occlusion and ischemia. It can result in Erlenmeyer flask deformity, osteonecrosis, and fractures. D. Are often diaphyseal in sickle cell disease Sickle cell disease causes vaso-occlusion and bone infarcts, particularly in the diaphysis of long bones. It can lead to "bone within a bone" appearance and H-shaped vertebrae. E. Are seen in acute pancreatitis Acute pancreatitis can cause fat embolism, leading to bone infarcts, especially in the femoral head and metaphyseal regions.

choices.text: Fracture transverse process of lumbar vertebra

questions.text: Beheaded Scottish terrier sign is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Spondylolisthesis. The "Beheaded Scottish Terrier Sign" is a radiological finding seen in spondylolisthesis, particularly due to spondylolysis (a defect in the pars interarticularis). It is best visualized on an oblique lumbar spine X-ray. Normally, in an oblique view of the lumbar spine, the pars interarticularis forms the "neck" of a Scottish Terrier-like shape. In spondylolysis, the pars interarticularis defect creates a gap in the "neck", making the "head" appear separated from the body, giving the "beheaded Scottish Terrier" appearance. If spondylolysis progresses to spondylolisthesis, the vertebral body moves anteriorly, worsening the defect. Incorrect Options: A. Spondylosis Spondylosis refers to degenerative changes in the spine (such as osteophyte formation and disc degeneration). It does not cause a pars interarticularis defect or the beheaded Scottish Terrier sign. C. Fracture of the Transverse Process of the Lumbar Vertebra Transverse process fractures result from direct trauma or muscle avulsion and do not resemble the Scottish Terrier sign. D. Fracture of Rib Rib fractures are diagnosed using chest X-rays, and they do not involve the vertebral anatomy necessary to produce the Scottish Terrier appearance. E. Fracture of Scaphoid Scaphoid fractures occur in the wrist, typically diagnosed using wrist X-rays, and have no relation to the Scottish Terrier sign seen in the lumbar spine.

questions.text: Scottish terrier sign is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Oblique view. The Scottish Terrier Sign is a radiological appearance seen in an oblique X-ray of the lumbar spine. It occurs due to the bony anatomy of the vertebrae, where different parts of the vertebra resemble a Scottish Terrier dog: Ear → Superior articular process Eye → Pedicle Nose → Transverse process Front leg → Inferior articular process Neck → Pars interarticularis In spondylolysis (pars interarticularis defect), the "neck" of the Scottish Terrier appears fractured, leading to the "Collar Sign". If there is anterior displacement (spondylolisthesis), the head appears "beheaded," forming the "Beheaded Scottish Terrier Sign". Incorrect Options: A. AP view The anteroposterior (AP) view does not provide the three-dimensional perspective needed to visualize the Scottish Terrier appearance. B. PA view The posteroanterior (PA) view is not typically used for lumbar spine assessment and does not show the Scottish Terrier sign. C. Lateral view The lateral view is useful for assessing spondylolisthesis but does not display the Scottish Terrier sign.

questions.text: Investigation of choice in parathyroid pathology is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tc-Sestamibi Scan. The Technetium-99m Sestamibi (Tc-99m Sestamibi) scan is the investigation of choice for detecting parathyroid adenomas and hyperplasia in primary hyperparathyroidism. It works by using a radioactive tracer (Tc-99m Sestamibi), which is preferentially absorbed by hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue. This allows for accurate localization of abnormal parathyroid glands before surgery (parathyroidectomy). It is non-invasive, highly sensitive, and specific for identifying ectopic or multiple adenomas. Often combined with SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) for better anatomical localization. Incorrect Options: A. CT Scan CT scans are not the primary imaging modality for parathyroid pathology. However, 4D-CT is used in cases where Tc-99m Sestamibi scanning is inconclusive, especially in recurrent or ectopic parathyroid adenomas. B. Gallium Scan Gallium scans are primarily used for detecting infections, tumors, and lymphoma, but they are not specific for parathyroid pathology. C. Thallium Scan Thallium-201 scans were previously used for parathyroid imaging but have been largely replaced by Tc-99m Sestamibi due to better accuracy and imaging quality.

questions.text: Calcification of meniscal cartilage is feature of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pseudogout. Calcification of the meniscal cartilage, also known as chondrocalcinosis, is a characteristic feature of pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease, CPPD). Pseudogout results from the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals in the articular cartilage, leading to calcification, particularly in the menisci of the knee, symphysis pubis, and triangular fibrocartilage of the wrist. Radiographic findings include linear calcifications within the cartilage (chondrocalcinosis), particularly in the knee, wrist, and pubic symphysis. Incorrect Options: A. Acromegaly Acromegaly can cause cartilage hypertrophy and joint space widening, but it does not typically cause meniscal cartilage calcification. B. Hyperparathyroidism Hyperparathyroidism can cause subperiosteal resorption, brown tumors, and osteitis fibrosa cystica, but it does not primarily cause meniscal calcification. However, it may lead to vascular and periarticular soft tissue calcifications. C. Reiter's Syndrome (Reactive Arthritis) Reiter’s syndrome (reactive arthritis) is associated with asymmetric arthritis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis, but it does not cause meniscal cartilage calcification.

questions.text: The posterior iliac horn is characteristic of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nail-Patella Syndrome. Posterior Iliac Horns are pathognomonic (highly characteristic) of Nail-Patella Syndrome (NPS), also known as hereditary osteo-onychodysplasia (HOOD syndrome). NPS is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the LMX1B gene. Posterior iliac horns are bilateral, symmetrical, bony projections on the posterior aspect of the iliac bones, seen on pelvic X-rays. They are asymptomatic and help in the radiological diagnosis of NPS. Other features of Nail-Patella Syndrome include: - Nail abnormalities (hypoplastic, ridged, or absent nails). - Skeletal anomalies (elbow dysplasia, patellar hypoplasia). - Renal involvement (nephropathy, proteinuria). - Glaucoma or ocular defects. Incorrect Options: B. Marfan's Syndrome Marfan’s syndrome is a connective tissue disorder affecting the fibrillin-1 gene (FBN1). It causes tall stature, long limbs (arachnodactyly), lens dislocation, and aortic aneurysm, but does not cause posterior iliac horns. C. Hurler Syndrome Hurler syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis type I, MPS I) is a lysosomal storage disorder due to α-L-iduronidase deficiency. It leads to skeletal dysplasia (dysostosis multiplex), coarse facial features, and hepatosplenomegaly, but not posterior iliac horns. D. Acromegaly Acromegaly is caused by excess growth hormone (GH) secretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It leads to enlarged hands, feet, facial bones, and thickened skull, but does not cause posterior iliac horns.

questions.text: Epiphyseal enlargement is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis (JRA) Epiphyseal enlargement refers to an increase in the size of the epiphysis due to inflammation, hyperemia, or abnormal bone growth. It is commonly seen in Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis (JRA) due to chronic synovitis and hyperemia, which stimulate excessive bone growth in the epiphyseal region. JRA Features on X-ray: Epiphyseal enlargement Widened intercondylar notch (especially in the knee joint) Soft tissue swelling Osteopenia due to chronic inflammation Incorrect Options: A. Rickets – Causes Metaphyseal Changes, Not Epiphyseal Enlargement Rickets leads to widening and fraying of the metaphysis, not epiphyseal enlargement. Characteristic signs include "cupping, fraying, and splaying" of the metaphysis. B. Ankylosing Spondylitis – Affects Sacroiliac Joints, Not Epiphysis Ankylosing spondylitis is primarily a spinal and sacroiliac joint disease. Radiographic features include bamboo spine, squaring of vertebrae, and sacroiliitis, but not epiphyseal enlargement. C. Spondyloepiphyseal Dysplasia – Causes Epiphyseal Dysplasia, Not Enlargement A genetic disorder affecting bone growth, leading to epiphyseal dysplasia and irregular ossification rather than true enlargement. Commonly presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and spinal abnormalities.

questions.text: Geographic lytic lesions in the vault of the skull with bevelled edges are seen with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Eosinophilic Granuloma. Eosinophilic Granuloma (Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis - LCH) is a disorder characterized by the proliferation of Langerhans cells, which can lead to bone lesions. Radiological hallmark: Geographic lytic lesions with beveled edges in the skull vault. These occur due to asymmetric destruction of the inner and outer skull tables, giving a beveled appearance. Sometimes called "hole-within-hole" appearance. Common sites: Skull, mandible, ribs, vertebrae ("vertebra plana"), and long bones. Other clinical features: Painful or asymptomatic skull lesions. Can be solitary (Eosinophilic Granuloma) or part of systemic Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH). Incorrect Options: B. Multiple Myeloma Multiple Myeloma causes multiple "punched-out" lytic lesions in the skull but without beveled edges. These lesions are uniform, well-defined, and lack the asymmetry of LCH. C. Hyperparathyroidism Hyperparathyroidism leads to subperiosteal bone resorption and salt-and-pepper skull appearance rather than discrete geographic lytic lesions. It is associated with brown tumors but does not show beveled edges. D. Reticular Cell Carcinoma (Histiocytic Lymphoma) This is a rare lymphoma variant, which may involve bone, but it does not classically cause geographic skull lesions with beveled edges.

questions.text: In scurvy all of the following radiological signs are seen except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Soap Bubble Appearance (which is not seen in scurvy). Soap bubble appearance is seen in osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumor - GCT). It is characterized by expansile, lytic lesions with a thin bony trabeculated cortex, which is not a feature of scurvy. Scurvy (Vitamin C Deficiency) affects bone growth and leads to characteristic radiological signs due to defective collagen synthesis and impaired bone mineralization. Correct Radiological Signs in Scurvy: (A) Pelican Spur This refers to protruding metaphyseal spurs, resembling a beak at the ends of long bones. Caused by subperiosteal hemorrhage and periosteal reaction. (C) Zone of Demarcation Near Epiphysis Also known as the Wimberger’s Ring Sign, it appears as a well-defined white line around the epiphysis due to defective bone turnover. (D) Frenkel’s Line Also called the White Line of Frankel, it is a dense white line at the metaphysis due to defective bone resorption.

questions.text: About osteogenesis imperfecta; all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Metaphyseal fractures (which is not typically seen in Osteogenesis Imperfecta). Metaphyseal fractures are more characteristic of Rickets or Child Abuse (battered baby syndrome). In OI, fractures commonly involve the diaphysis rather than the metaphysis. Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) – Key Features: Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen (Type I collagen defect) leading to bone fragility, recurrent fractures, and connective tissue abnormalities. Incorrect Option: A. Diaphyseal fractures OI primarily leads to diaphyseal fractures (midshaft fractures of long bones) due to bone fragility and reduced cortical thickness. Recurrent fractures cause bone deformities like bowing of femur and tibia. C. Classified by Sillence Classification OI is classified using Sillence Classification, which includes Types I–IV (with additional subtypes described later). Type I – Mildest, blue sclera. Type II – Most severe, perinatal lethal. Type III – Severe, progressive deformities. Type IV – Moderate severity. D. Scleral and dental abnormalities Blue sclera (due to thinning of collagen in the sclera). Dentinogenesis imperfecta (weak, discolored, translucent teeth).

questions.text: The gold standard for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA/ DXA). Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA) is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis because it provides a precise and quantitative measurement of bone mineral density (BMD). Why DEXA is the best choice? Measures BMD at hip, lumbar spine, and forearm (most fracture-prone sites). Highly sensitive and reproducible. Used to calculate T-score and Z-score, which help in osteoporosis diagnosis. T-score ≤ -2.5 confirms osteoporosis as per WHO criteria. Incorrect Options: B. Single Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (SXA) Measures BMD but only in peripheral sites (forearm, heel). Less accurate and not widely used for osteoporosis diagnosis. C. Ultrasonography Quantitative Ultrasound (QUS) is used for screening but not for definitive diagnosis. Measures bone quality at heel or tibia, but lacks precision compared to DEXA. D. Quantitative Computed Tomography (QCT) Measures volumetric BMD but exposes patients to higher radiation. More expensive and not routinely used for osteoporosis screening.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presented with a slowly progressive swelling in the middle third of his right tibia. X-ray examination revealed multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions separated by areas of dense and sclerotic bone. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen revealed island of epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Adamantinoma. Adamantinoma is a rare, low-grade malignant bone tumor that primarily affects the tibia, usually in young adults. It presents as a slowly progressive swelling and has a distinctive histopathological feature: epithelial islands within a fibrous stroma. This epithelial component is a hallmark of adamantinoma and is not seen in other bone tumors. Clinical Features: Most commonly affects the middle third of the tibia. Slowly growing, painless swelling over months to years. Typically affects young adults (20–40 years old). Radiological Features: Multiple, sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions. Areas of dense and sclerotic bone interspersed within the lesion. Cortical thinning and possible expansion of the bone. Histological Features: Islands of epithelial cells within a fibrous stroma. The presence of epithelial elements differentiates adamantinoma from other bone lesions. Incorrect Options B. Osteofibrous Dysplasia Similar in location (tibia) and radiological appearance, but: More common in children (<10 years old) rather than adults. Histology lacks epithelial islands, which are a hallmark of adamantinoma. Considered a benign lesion and does not progress to malignancy. C. Osteosarcoma Aggressive tumor with: Rapid growth, pain, and soft tissue invasion, unlike the slow progression of adamantinoma. X-ray features include: Codman’s triangle (periosteal elevation). Sunburst pattern (aggressive periosteal reaction). Histology shows malignant osteoid production, not epithelial islands. D. Fibrous Cortical Defect Benign, self-limiting lesion, usually seen in children and adolescents. Small, well-circumscribed radiolucent lesions found in the metaphysis, not in the diaphysis. No epithelial cells in histology, making it different from adamantinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following usually produces osteoblastic secondaries?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Carcinoma Prostate Prostate cancer is the most common malignancy associated with osteoblastic (bone-forming) metastases. Unlike most cancers that cause osteolytic (bone-destroying) lesions, prostate cancer typically induces new bone formation, leading to sclerotic (dense) bone lesions seen on imaging. These lesions can cause bone pain and pathological fractures but are distinct due to their increased bone density. Tumor cells release bone growth factors, such as bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) and endothelin-1, which stimulate osteoblast activity and new bone formation. The spine, pelvis, and proximal femur are common sites of metastases. X-ray and bone scans typically show diffuse or focal sclerotic lesions in affected bones. Incorrect Options: A. Carcinoma Lung → Usually Osteolytic Lung cancer, especially non-small cell lung carcinoma, usually causes osteolytic metastases, leading to destructive bone lesions. Small cell lung cancer, in rare cases, may cause mixed or sclerotic lesions, but it is not the typical presentation. B. Carcinoma Breast → Mixed (Osteolytic & Osteoblastic) Breast cancer metastases can be osteolytic, osteoblastic, or mixed. Lytic lesions occur more commonly due to parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP), which increases bone resorption. Some subtypes, like lobular carcinoma, may produce osteoblastic secondaries, but this is less common than osteolytic lesions. C. Carcinoma Urinary Bladder → Usually Osteolytic Bladder cancer primarily causes osteolytic bone metastases, leading to bone destruction rather than bone formation. It typically spreads to the pelvis, spine, and ribs, causing pain and fractures

questions.text: Expansile type osseous metastases are characteristic of primary malignancy of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Kidney (Renal Cell Carcinoma). Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is one of the primary malignancies known to produce expansile, lytic osseous metastases. Unlike most other cancers that cause bone destruction in a non-expansile manner, RCC metastases tend to expand the bone while eroding it. These metastases can appear ballooned, lytic, and well-defined on radiographs, often resembling a "blow-out" lesion rather than a typical destructive or sclerotic metastasis. Highly vascular tumor that promotes bone destruction but also stimulates surrounding bone growth, leading to an expansile appearance. Metastases commonly involve vertebrae, pelvis, femur, and humerus, increasing the risk of pathological fractures. Radiographic features: Large, lytic, expansile lesions with a soap-bubble-like appearance. Incorrect Options: B. Bronchus (Lung Cancer) Lung cancer metastases are mostly osteolytic rather than expansile. They cause rapid bone destruction, leading to pathological fractures, but they do not expand the bone. Some small cell lung cancers can cause osteoblastic metastases, but expansile lesions are uncommon. C. Breast Cancer Breast cancer metastases are typically osteolytic, osteoblastic, or mixed, but they do not produce expansile lesions. Lytic lesions result from tumor-induced bone resorption, while osteoblastic lesions occur due to abnormal bone formation. Common sites of metastases: Spine, pelvis, ribs, and femur. D. Prostate Cancer Prostate cancer primarily causes osteoblastic (sclerotic) metastases, not expansile lytic lesions. Metastases appear as dense, sclerotic areas on X-ray rather than large, ballooned, destructive lesions. Most commonly affects the spine, pelvis, and proximal femur

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to present as an eccentric osteolytic lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Simple Bone Cyst A simple bone cyst (unicameral bone cyst, UBC) is least likely to present as an eccentric osteolytic lesion. Instead, it typically appears as a central osteolytic lesion in the metaphysis of long bones, especially in the proximal humerus and proximal femur of children and adolescents. UBCs are usually centrally located within the medullary cavity. They have well-defined, radiolucent, and unilocular appearance. They are often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally unless complicated by a fracture (fallen fragment sign). Incorrect Options: A. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) → Typically Eccentric ABC is a benign, expansile, osteolytic lesion filled with blood-filled spaces. It is eccentric, commonly affecting long bones (femur, tibia) and vertebrae. X-rays show a soap-bubble or blown-out appearance. B. Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) → Typically Eccentric GCT is a locally aggressive osteolytic tumor seen in young adults (20-40 years). It is eccentric, located in the epiphysis and metaphysis of long bones, especially the distal femur and proximal tibia. It has a characteristic "soap bubble" appearance on X-ray. C. Fibrous Cortical Defect → Typically Eccentric Also called non-ossifying fibroma, this lesion is eccentric and located in the metaphysis of long bones. It appears as a small, well-defined, radiolucent cortical lesion. It is self-limiting and usually asymptomatic.

questions.text: Brown tumours are seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hyperparathyroidism Brown tumors (also called osteitis fibrosa cystica) are bone lesions that develop due to excessive osteoclastic activity in hyperparathyroidism. These lesions are a result of increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, leading to: Excessive bone resorption → osteolytic lesions Replacement by fibrous tissue → formation of cyst-like spaces Deposition of hemosiderin from microhemorrhages, giving them a characteristic brown color They are most commonly found in ribs, pelvis, femur, and mandible and appear as lytic, expansile lesions on radiographs. Incorrect Options: B. Pigmented Villonodular Synovitis (PVNS) PVNS is a synovial joint disorder, not a bone disease. It is characterized by proliferation of hemosiderin-laden synovial cells and affects joints, especially the knee. It does not cause osteolytic lesions like brown tumors. C. Osteomalacia Osteomalacia is caused by defective bone mineralization due to vitamin D deficiency. It leads to diffuse bone softening and Looser’s zones (pseudofractures) rather than focal lytic lesions. It does not produce brown tumors. D. Neurofibromatosis Neurofibromatosis causes skeletal dysplasias, including kyphoscoliosis, vertebral scalloping, and sphenoid wing dysplasia. It is not associated with brown tumors or osteolytic lesions due to PTH excess.

questions.text: Heberden's nodes are found in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) DIP joints in osteoarthritis Heberden's nodes are bony outgrowths (osteophytes) found at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints. They are a characteristic feature of osteoarthritis (OA) and result from: Cartilage degeneration Osteophyte formation at the joint margins Chronic wear and tear on the joint These nodes appear as hard, swollen, and sometimes painful enlargements over the DIP joints, commonly seen in older individuals, especially postmenopausal women. Incorrect Options: A. PIP joints in osteoarthritis Osteoarthritis affects both DIP and PIP joints, but Heberden’s nodes are specific to DIP joints. Bouchard’s nodes, not Heberden’s nodes, occur at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints in osteoarthritis. C. PIP joints in rheumatoid arthritis Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) primarily affects the PIP and MCP joints, but it does not cause Heberden’s nodes. Instead, RA leads to joint inflammation, synovitis, and deformities like swan-neck and boutonnière deformities. D. DIP joints in rheumatoid arthritis RA rarely affects the DIP joints, as it mainly involves MCP and PIP joints. When DIP joint involvement is seen, it is usually in psoriatic arthritis, not RA. Heberden’s nodes are not seen in RA.

choices.text: Parenchymal pulmonary lesions on chest films

questions.text: Which one of the following is the earliest radiographic manifestation of childhood leukemia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Radiolucent transverse metaphyseal bands The earliest radiographic manifestation of childhood leukemia is the presence of radiolucent transverse metaphyseal bands (also called "leukemic lines"). These appear as: Symmetric, transverse, radiolucent bands at the metaphysis of long bones. Most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. Thought to result from marrow infiltration and disruption of normal bone metabolism. These changes are highly suggestive of leukemia in a child presenting with musculoskeletal symptoms. Incorrect Options: B. Diffuse demineralization of bones Generalized osteopenia is a later finding in leukemia. It occurs due to bone marrow infiltration leading to increased osteoclastic activity and decreased bone formation. However, it is not the earliest sign. C. Osteoblastic lesions in skull Leukemia typically causes osteolytic (not osteoblastic) lesions in the skull. Osteoblastic lesions are more characteristic of osteosarcoma or metastatic prostate cancer, not leukemia. D. Parenchymal pulmonary lesions on chest films Pulmonary infiltrates can be seen in leukemia due to infection (opportunistic or leukemic infiltration).

questions.text: 60 years old man with sensorineural deafness and bony abnormality in left leg has S.Ca²+ -9.5 and alkaline phosphate 440 mull skeletal survey shows ivory vertebra and cotton-wool spots on skull most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Paget's Disease The most probable diagnosis in this 60-year-old man with sensorineural hearing loss and bony abnormalities is Paget’s disease of bone (Osteitis Deformans). The key supporting features in the case include: Normal serum calcium (S.Ca²+ = 9.5 mg/dL) → Paget’s disease typically has normal calcium levels in the absence of fractures. Markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP = 440 IU/L) → Reflects increased bone turnover, characteristic of Paget’s disease. Ivory vertebra → Represents diffuse bony sclerosis, commonly seen in Paget’s disease. Cotton-wool spots on skull X-ray → A classic finding in Paget’s disease due to disorganized bone remodeling. Sensorineural deafness → Occurs due to temporal bone involvement leading to cochlear nerve compression. Paget’s disease is a chronic disorder of bone remodeling characterized by excessive bone resorption and disorganized new bone formation, leading to structurally weak and abnormally enlarged bones. Incorrect Options: B. Osteosclerotic Metastasis Ivory vertebra can be seen in osteoblastic metastases (e.g., prostate, breast cancer). However, cotton-wool spots on the skull are not a feature of metastasis. Metastatic disease typically has multiple lytic or sclerotic lesions, not the characteristic mosaic bone pattern of Paget’s. C. Osteoporosis Osteoporosis leads to diffuse bone loss and fragility fractures, not bone sclerosis (ivory vertebra). Serum ALP is usually normal in osteoporosis unless there is a fracture. Cotton-wool skull appearance is not seen in osteoporosis. D. Fibrous Dysplasia Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental disorder of bone, presenting with ground-glass bone appearance, not ivory vertebra or cotton-wool skull. It does not significantly elevate alkaline phosphatase like Paget’s disease. Sensorineural deafness can occur in McCune-Albright syndrome, but it is associated with café-au-lait spots and endocrine abnormalities, which are absent in this case.

questions.text: Bohler's angle is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Calcaneum Böhler's angle (also called the Tuber Angle of Böhler) is an important radiographic measurement used to assess calcaneal fractures. It is formed by the intersection of two lines drawn on a lateral X-ray of the foot: A line from the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus to the highest point of the posterior facet. A line from the highest point of the posterior facet to the highest point of the calcaneal tuberosity. Normal Böhler’s angle: 20°–40°. Decreased Böhler’s angle (< 20°) is indicative of a calcaneal fracture. Incorrect Options: B. Talus Böhler’s angle is specifically used for the calcaneus, not the talus. The talus is assessed using the Hawkins classification for fractures and talar tilt angle. C. Navicular Navicular fractures are commonly seen in stress injuries (e.g., runners) and are best assessed by CT scan or MRI, not Böhler’s angle. D. Cuboid The cuboid is a wedge-shaped tarsal bone, and fractures here are assessed using CT scans rather than Böhler’s angle.

questions.text: Hair on end appearance is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thalassemia "Hair on end" appearance is a characteristic radiological finding seen in conditions with marrow hyperplasia, leading to expansion of the diploic spaces in the skull. This appearance is due to excessive erythropoiesis causing new bone formation along the periosteum, which creates a striated or spiculated pattern on skull X-rays. Most commonly seen in Thalassemia major, where chronic hemolysis leads to erythroid hyperplasia and bone marrow expansion. Incorrect Options: B. Scurvy → Incorrect Scurvy causes subperiosteal hemorrhage and the "white line of Frankel" but not marrow hyperplasia or hair-on-end appearance. C. Rickets → Incorrect Rickets leads to widened, frayed metaphyses and bowing of long bones due to defective mineralization, but it does not cause vertical striations in the skull. D. Sickle Cell Disease → Partially Correct but Less Common Can show hair on end appearance, but less frequently than thalassemia. More commonly, SCD causes infarcts and osteonecrosis, not just marrow expansion.

questions.text: A child presents with multiple vertebral anomalies and a posterior mediastinal mass. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Neurenteric cyst is cystic mass of the posterior mediastinum of foregut origin, secondary to an abnormality of certain developing mesodermal and endodermal structures during the third week of embryogenesis. Anterior fusion anomalies of the cervical and thoracic spine occur in almost 40 per cent of patients, and the combination of findings is virtually diagnostic.

questions.text: Fraying of anterior ends of ribs is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rickets Fraying of the anterior ends of the ribs is a characteristic radiological finding in rickets. This occurs due to defective mineralization of the growing bones, leading to irregular, widened, and frayed costochondral junctions. This appearance is commonly described as "rachitic rosary", where the costochondral junctions become prominent and nodular due to cartilage overgrowth. Other radiological features of rickets include: Fraying, cupping, and splaying of metaphyses. Loss of the provisional zone of calcification. Bowing of long bones due to poor bone strength. Incorrect Options: A. Scurvy Scurvy affects the bones due to vitamin C deficiency, causing subperiosteal hemorrhages and cortical thinning. The rib changes in scurvy are different, with Pelkan spur and Wimberger’s ring sign, not fraying. C. Down Syndrome Down syndrome is associated with hypotonia, atlantoaxial instability, and delayed skeletal development, but not fraying of ribs. D. Osteoporosis Osteoporosis causes generalized bone demineralization and cortical thinning, but does not cause fraying or widening of costochondral junctions.

questions.text: Floating teeth is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hyperparathyroidism "Floating teeth" refers to the radiographic appearance where teeth appear to be suspended in space without visible bone support. This is primarily due to severe bone resorption around the teeth, which is seen in Hyperparathyroidism. Mechanism in Hyperparathyroidism: Subperiosteal bone resorption (hallmark feature), leading to loss of cortical bone. Loss of lamina dura around teeth, creating the floating teeth appearance. Generalized osteopenia, leading to fragile bones. Other radiographic signs: Pepper pot skull / Salt and pepper skull (mottled appearance of the skull due to resorption). Subperiosteal resorption at the radial aspect of middle phalanx of 2nd and 3rd fingers. Brown tumors (osteoclast-rich bone lesions due to excessive PTH). Incorrect Options: B. Hypoparathyroidism – No Bone Resorption Hypoparathyroidism leads to increased bone density due to low PTH levels, not resorption. Common features include calcification of basal ganglia and hyperdense bones, but not floating teeth. C. Rickets – Causes Metaphyseal Changes, Not Floating Teeth Rickets leads to defective mineralization of bone, causing widened growth plates and bowing of long bones, but it does not cause loss of alveolar bone around teeth. Characteristic radiographic findings include "fraying, cupping, and splaying" of metaphyses. D. Scurvy – Causes Subperiosteal Bleeding, Not Bone Resorption Scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency) leads to bleeding and weakened bone structure, but not direct resorption. Key signs include "Pelkan spurs," Wimberger ring sign (white line of scurvy), and subperiosteal hemorrhages.

questions.text: Characteristic radiological feature of fibrous dysplasia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ground Glass Appearance The characteristic radiological feature of fibrous dysplasia is the "ground glass appearance" of the affected bone. This occurs due to the replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue and disorganized trabeculae, leading to a homogeneous hazy appearance on X-ray. Fibrous dysplasia is a benign bone disorder that can involve a single bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic). The ground glass appearance is seen due to poorly mineralized woven bone, which gives a uniform hazy density. Other radiological features include: Bone expansion with endosteal scalloping. No periosteal reaction (distinguishing it from other lytic lesions). Shepherd’s crook deformity in the femur due to bowing. Incorrect Options: A. Thickened Bone Matrix Fibrous dysplasia does not cause thickening of the bone matrix. Instead, it replaces the normal bone with fibrous tissue, making the bone appear less dense rather than thickened. Thickened bone matrix is more characteristic of conditions like Paget’s disease or osteopetrosis. B. Cortical Erosion Fibrous dysplasia does not cause significant cortical erosion. Instead, the cortex remains intact but may appear thinned or scalloped due to expansion of the lesion. Cortical erosion is more commonly seen in aggressive bone tumors or infections like osteomyelitis. D. Bone Enlargement Although fibrous dysplasia can cause bone expansion, it is due to the replacement of bone with fibrous tissue, not true hypertrophy or overgrowth of the bone. The key radiological hallmark remains the ground glass appearance, while bone enlargement is a secondary effect.

questions.text: "Tear drop sign" is seen on Waters view in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Blowout Fracture The "tear drop sign" is a radiological finding seen on Waters view (Occipitomental view) of the skull, most commonly associated with blowout fractures of the orbit. A blowout fracture typically occurs due to blunt trauma to the orbit, leading to a fracture of the orbital floor (maxillary sinus roof). The tear drop sign appears as a soft tissue opacity hanging into the maxillary sinus, representing herniated orbital contents (fat, muscle, or soft tissue). This is often associated with diplopia, enophthalmos, and infraorbital nerve damage (causing numbness over the cheek and upper lip). Incorrect Options: B. Maxillary Mucocele A maxillary mucocele presents as a homogeneous radiopaque mass within the maxillary sinus but does not cause a tear drop appearance. It results from chronic obstruction of the sinus ostium, leading to mucus accumulation. C. Nasolacrimal Duct Blockage Nasolacrimal duct obstruction typically leads to dilatation of the lacrimal sac (dacryocystocele), visible in imaging of the medial orbit, not as a tear drop sign in the maxillary sinus. D. Fibrous Dysplasia Fibrous dysplasia affects the bony structure, leading to ground glass opacity rather than the displacement of orbital contents. It is not associated with blowout fractures or soft tissue herniation into the sinus

questions.text: Symptomatic spinal injury without any radiological evidence most commonly found in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Children Symptomatic spinal injury without radiological evidence (SCIWORA - Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiographic Abnormality) is most commonly seen in children. In children, the spinal column is more flexible and elastic, while the spinal cord is relatively less elastic. This makes the spinal cord vulnerable to injury even without visible fractures or dislocations on X-rays or CT scans. The underdeveloped musculature and ligamentous structures in children contribute to this phenomenon. MRI is the preferred imaging modality for detecting soft tissue and spinal cord injuries in such cases. Incorrect Options: B. Elderly In elderly individuals, spinal injuries are often associated with degenerative changes, osteoporosis, and fractures, which are usually detectable on radiographs. SCIWORA is rare in older adults due to decreased flexibility of the spine. C. Teenagers While teenagers can experience spinal injuries, their spinal column is more mature and less flexible compared to children, making SCIWORA less common. Fractures and dislocations are more likely to be seen on imaging in this age group. D. Young Adults Young adults usually sustain high-impact spinal trauma (e.g., from motor vehicle accidents or sports injuries), which more often leads to detectable fractures or dislocations. SCIWORA is uncommon in this group.

questions.text: "Looser's zones" can be characteristically seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osteomalacia Looser’s zones, also known as pseudofractures or Milkman’s fractures, are characteristically seen in osteomalacia. Osteomalacia is a metabolic bone disorder caused by defective mineralization of bone matrix, often due to vitamin D deficiency. Looser’s zones are bilateral, symmetrical, and transverse radiolucent lines that appear in areas of mechanical stress, such as the pubic rami, ribs, scapula, medial femur, and ulna. These lesions do not extend completely through the bone and are often associated with bone pain and weakness. Incorrect Options: B. Paget’s Disease Paget’s disease is characterized by excessive bone remodeling, leading to thickened, deformed, and structurally weak bones. The characteristic radiological findings in Paget’s disease include cotton wool appearance of the skull, osteoporosis circumscripta, and blade of grass sign, but Looser’s zones are not a common feature. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder of collagen synthesis, leading to brittle bones and multiple fractures. While OI can present with fractures, Looser’s zones (pseudofractures) are not a characteristic finding. Classic radiological findings of OI include wormian bones in the skull and bowing of long bones. D. All of the Above Since Looser’s zones are characteristic of osteomalacia and not a feature of Paget’s disease or osteogenesis imperfecta, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A child presents with a history of injury to left forefinger tip with a glass piece. On examination, the finger is swollen and tender. Which of the following would be the best investigation to determine the glass foreign body in the patient's finger?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neuroenteric Cyst A neuroenteric cyst is a cystic mass in the posterior mediastinum that arises from foregut remnants due to abnormal development of mesodermal and endodermal structures during embryogenesis. Strong association with vertebral anomalies Around 40% of cases show anterior fusion anomalies of the cervical and thoracic spine. This includes hemivertebrae, butterfly vertebrae, and vertebral body fusion defects. Commonly found in infants and children Located in the posterior mediastinum, often near the spinal canal Symptoms may include respiratory distress, dysphagia, or neurological deficits (if spinal involvement is present). Since this combination of vertebral anomalies and a posterior mediastinal mass is highly characteristic of neuroenteric cysts, this is the most likely diagnosis. Incorrect Options: B. Meningomyelocele – No Posterior Mediastinal Mass Meningomyelocele is a neural tube defect with herniation of meninges and spinal cord. It occurs in the lumbosacral region, not the posterior mediastinum. C. Bronchogenic Cyst – No Vertebral Anomalies A bronchogenic cyst is a congenital foregut duplication cyst, usually found in the middle mediastinum. It is not associated with vertebral anomalies. D. Neuroblastoma – More Common in Adrenal or Paraspinal Areas Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumor arising from neural crest cells of the sympathetic chain. It can occur in the posterior mediastinum, but it is not associated with vertebral anomalies.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with severe bone pains at multiple sites. Plain radiographs reveal multiple lytic lesions in pelvis, ribs and femur, fracture of the clavicles and subperiosteal reabsorption of metacarpals over the radial aspect. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most likely diagnosis in this middle-aged female with severe bone pain, multiple lytic lesions, fractures, and subperiosteal resorption is hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) results in excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to increased bone resorption and characteristic skeletal changes. Radiological features include: Multiple lytic lesions (brown tumors due to osteoclastic activity) in the pelvis, ribs, and femur. Fractures, especially in weight-bearing bones. Subperiosteal resorption of the radial aspect of metacarpals, which is a hallmark of hyperparathyroidism. Salt and pepper appearance of the skull (due to trabecular resorption). Rugger-jersey spine (sclerosis of vertebral endplates). This condition is commonly associated with parathyroid adenoma or hyperplasia and may lead to osteitis fibrosa cystica in severe cases. Incorrect Options: A. Hyperthyroidism Hyperthyroidism can cause osteopenia and osteoporosis but does not cause multiple lytic lesions or subperiosteal resorption. Bone pain is not a prominent feature, and fractures are usually due to chronic bone loss rather than direct resorption. C. Renal Osteodystrophy Renal osteodystrophy is seen in chronic kidney disease (CKD) and involves secondary hyperparathyroidism. It can cause subperiosteal resorption, but multiple lytic lesions (brown tumors) are less common. It also presents with osteomalacia-like features, soft tissue calcifications, and rugger-jersey spine, but no mention of CKD is provided in the history. D. Osteomalacia Osteomalacia is due to vitamin D deficiency or defective mineralization and presents with bone pain, fractures, and Looser's zones (pseudofractures). It does not cause subperiosteal resorption or multiple lytic lesions, which are characteristic of hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Sun-ray appearance in osteosarcoma is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Periosteal Reaction The sun-ray appearance in osteosarcoma is due to an aggressive periosteal reaction caused by the rapid growth of malignant bone-forming cells. As the tumor expands, it stimulates the periosteum to produce spiculated bone formations, which radiate outward in a sunburst pattern. This spiculated periosteal reaction occurs because the tumor invades and lifts the periosteum, leading to the deposition of perpendicular bony spicules. This feature is highly suggestive of osteosarcoma, a highly aggressive bone tumor, typically affecting the metaphysis of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus) in adolescents and young adults. Incorrect Options: A. Osteonecrosis Osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis) leads to bone infarction, but it does not cause a sun-ray appearance. Instead, it shows patchy sclerosis, subchondral collapse (crescent sign), and joint space narrowing. C. Calcification along the muscle spindles Muscle spindle calcifications occur in conditions like myositis ossificans, but they do not produce a radiating sunburst periosteal pattern. Myositis ossificans appears as a well-demarcated, ossified mass with a zonal pattern of calcification. D. Calcification along the vessels Vascular calcifications occur in conditions like Monckeberg's arteriosclerosis or chronic kidney disease, but they appear as linear or circular calcifications along arteries, not as spiculated bone formation.

questions.text: Which abnormality is represented in the radiological image given below?
questions.solution: X-ray shows Beheaded scottish dog appearance – Spondylolisthesis The Scottie dog sign refers to the normal appearance of the lumbar spine when seen on oblique radiographic projection.Scotty dog with collar is seen in spondylolysis
